titlestmt.subtitle: An Inventory of His Papers at the Minnesota Historical Society
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Dennis Meissner.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Lyda Morehouse, November 4, 1999.

change.item: Converted from EAD Version 1.0 to Version 2002 by Monica Manny Ralston, Daniel Sher, and Joyce Chapman.

did.head: OVERVIEW
did.abstract: Architectural drawings and plans, sketches of building facades, photographs, and project bidding specifications, all documenting a number of projects undertaken by Minneapolis architect Harry W. Jones.
did.physdesc: 3.0 cu. ft. (2 boxes and 2 oversize folders, unboxed).
did.physloc: See Detailed Description section for shelf locations.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHY OF HARRY WILD JONES
bioghist.p: Jones, the son of a Baptist clergyman, was born in Schoolcraft, Michigan on June 9, 1859. He attended Brown University for two years, then transferred to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and graduated from MIT in 1882. He came to Minneapolis in 1883, where he established an architectural practice in which he remained for the rest of his career. Although Jones specialized in ecclesiastical architecture, he also designed many private residences and public and commercial buildings in the Minneapolis area, as well as in a number of other places around the United States.

arrangement.head: ARRANGEMENT
arrangement.p: These documents are organized into the following sections:

relatedmaterial.head: RELATED MATERIALS
relatedmaterial.p: The scrapbook is probably the first of a set, the rest of which were apparently donated to the Hennepin County Historical Society, Minneapolis.

controlaccess.head: CATALOG HEADINGS
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the catalog of the Minnesota Historical Society. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons or places should search the catalog using these headings.

controlaccess.head: Organizations:
controlaccess.corpname: Bethlehem Swedish Lutheran Church (Minneapolis, Minn.)--Pictorial works.
Northfield Methodist Episcopal Church (Minneapolis, Minn.)--Pictorial works.
St. Cloud Presbyterian Church (Saint Cloud, Minn.)--Pictorial works.
Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church (Minneapolis, Minn.)--Pictorial works.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: [Indicate the cited item and/or series here]. Harry Wild Jones Papers. Minnesota Historical Society.

p.emph: See the Chicago Manual of Style for additional examples.

scopecontent.p: Two folders of miscellaneous papers (undated and 1924-1933) contain several small-format architectural drawings, sketches, and photographs of buildings designed by Jones, as well as detailed bidding specifications for several of his Minneapolis projects: Hiawatha Park skating pavilion, White House restaurant, a Sunday school addition to the Fourth Baptist Church, and an addition to the Simpson Methodist Episcopal Church. These architectural materials are accompanied by a newspaper article (1933) containing Jones' recollections of early days in the Washburn Park area of Minneapolis
Black and white photographic prints of eight Jones designs mounted on matboard. They are accompanied by a watercolor sketch of the facade of the First Baptist Church in Rockwell City, Iowa.
A black and white photograph of an unnamed brick residence tentatively identified as being in Northfield, Minnesota.

Contains many small-format architectural drawings, photographs, sketches, and newspaper accounts of buildings designed by Jones. Most are churches, but the volume also includes private residences, apartment buildings, public buildings, and commercial structures in Minneapolis and several other cities. One cyanotype photograph depicts the aftermath of the 1894 Minneapolis Lumber Exchange fire.
